data.text: I think that there are at least 4 possible scenarios. The first, and possibly the most laudable reason. People who have actively supported or have some direct connection to a charity decide they want to raise money for them and cycling is how they will achieve it. Second, people who are planning a long ride and see this as an opportunity to raise funds for a cause that they have sympathy with. Third, and probably the controvertial one here, people who see this as a way of funding thier own travel, whilst incidentally raising money for charity. This is because the rules that govern fundraising allow some of the monies raised to go towards paying expenses. Fourth, virtue signalling, or otherwise raising a social media presence. That is my 2c.

data.text: I have admired many who raise funds for a worthy charity, whether they ride an organized fundraising ride or independently as in the case of a cross country tour. I have had a few adverse experiences, though - One is that, while participating as both a rider and as a volunteer in an annual 125 mile ride, passersby come up and ask, "what is this for". My response is, "it's for fun". Typically, the question continues, "yes, but what are you raising money for?". Hmm, do I have to raise money in order to be allowed to ride my bike, or can I just ride because I want to? The second, again observed as both a participant and a volunteer, is that some of these people are not actually cyclists, they are 'people on bikes' (not a compliment). These POB often lack knowledge, or at least execution, of cycling courtesies like signalling, calling out 'on your left' holding their line, riding single file in traffic and following traffic controls. These POBs often make it riskier for the rest of us, either through erratic riding or irritating motorists. Once, I volunteered at a local stop in a fundraising ride that seemed to have a lot of college kids participating (early September). I was surprised when I would see a group ride in with identical carbon fiber bikes, then I realized they were rentals. These guys, some big athletic linebacker looking guys, typically just dropped these $2000 bikes on the asphalt parking lot; got off and dropped it. Not only was this inconsiderate of the next people to arrive, with these bikes scattered all over, but they had no respect for the bicycle itself. This was tough to watch; were I riding, I would have not only inflated the tires, but I would have inspected the bike, cleaned it's chain, adjusted the derailleurs, cleaned the wheels and spokes with rubbing alcohol, polished the frame and maybe even wiped the tires with a damp cloth. These guys just dropped 'em. I wanted to cry. If you are going to do distance riding, you have to take care of and respect your partner, your bike.

data.text: It is because if you look at the Cycling history it was used over the ages to promote and bring awareness about various things. In example, Tour De France started in order to increase sales for the newspaper L'Auto. Same with the Giro which was to increase sales and popularity of the La Gazetta dello Sport. In most cases people are doing a challenging route / event when asking for / collecting money i.e. ultra endurance events, everestings, 24h rides or in general rides or tours that are challenging in order to attract attention and as a result raise money for a certain cause. This is being implemented in other endurance sports such as running and swimming. I know it's banal but it is a way to get attention and raise some money for charity through the use of cycling. In my opinion when you're doing your regular ride (for me is between 100 - 120km with 2000- 2500m of elevation on a weekly basis) you can't turn it into a charity event. However, if I was going to do an everesting (8848m of elevation going up and down the same climb) I could've considered partnering with some kind of charitable foundation because everesting is challenging and can attract attention.
